sen.j: 兵糧（ひょうろう･兵粮）とは、戦争時における軍隊の食糧のこと。
sen.e: Hyoro is food supply for the army during times of war.
Hyoro is food supply for the army during times of war.
Hyoro is food supply for the army during times of war.

sen.j: 日本においては主食である米について論じられる事が多く、兵糧米（ひょうろうまい・兵粮米）などとも呼ばれている。
sen.e: In Japan, hyoro mainly means rice, the Japanese staple diet, and it is also said as hyoromai (provisions of rice for the army).
In Japan, hyoro mainly means rice, the Japanese staple diet, and it is also called hyoromai (provisions of rice for the army).
sen.cmt: said as → called の方が自然だと思われます。
sen.e: In Japan, hyoro mainly means rice, the Japanese staple diet, and it is also called hyoromai (provisions of rice for the army).

sen.j: 米の他にも食塩や大豆（ウマの食糧（馬糧）としても重要視された）なども含まれている。
sen.e: Except for rice, hyoro contains salt and soybean (which is emphasized as food supply for houses) and so on.
Except for rice, hyoro contains salt and soybean (which is emphasized as food supply for horses) and so on.
sen.cmt: スペルミス： houses → horses に訂正しました。
sen.e: Except for rice, hyoro contains salt and soybean (which is emphasized as food supply for horses) and so on.

sen.j: 古来から従軍する兵士には兵糧携帯の義務があり、律令法においては糒6斗及び塩2升の自弁が定められていたが、実際には60日分に過ぎず、かつ大量の兵糧携帯は場合によっては行軍の妨げになる可能性もあった。
sen.e: From ancient times a solder taking a part in a campaign was obliged to carry army provisions and, under Ritsuryo law, they had to pay his own expenses: about 108 liter of dried rice and about 3.6 liter of salt, however, these supply would last only 60 days and carrying a large amount of food could hinder a march.

From ancient times a soldier taking part in a campaign was obliged to carry army provisions and, under Ritsuryo law, they had to pay his own expenses: about 108 liter of dried rice and about 3.6 liter of salt, however, these supply would last only 60 days and carrying a large amount of food could hinder a march.
sen.cmt: スペルミス： solder → soldier に訂正しました。 文法ミス： taking a part → taking part に訂正しました。
sen.e: From ancient times a soldier taking part in a campaign was obliged to carry army provisions and, under Ritsuryo law, they had to pay his own expenses: about 108 liter of dried rice and about 3.6 liter of salt, however, these supply would last only 60 days and carrying a large amount of food could hinder a march.

sen.j: そこで、蝦夷討伐に際しては東国からの調達が許され、『延喜式』においては長門国の出挙4万束が兵粮料として充てることが定められている。
sen.e: Then, during the subjugation of Ezo (northerners), solders were allowed to supply food from Togoku (eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) provided that 40 thousand tsuka (bundle) of suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through 12th centuries) of Nagato Province is allotted for the military provisions.

Then, during the subjugation of Ezo (northerners), solders were allowed to supply food from Togoku (eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) provided that 40 thousand tsuka (bundle) of suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through 12th centuries) of Nagato Province is allotted for the military provisions.

Then, during the subjugation of Ezo (northerners), solders were allowed to supply food from Togoku (eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) provided that 40 thousand tsuka (bundle) of suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through 12th centuries) of Nagato Province is allotted for the military provisions.

sen.j: また、実際の軍事行動の際には地元有力者からの献納や徴発に頼ることが多かった。
sen.e: During the actual military affairs, they also relied on dedication and requisition to be supplied by locally influential people.
During the actual military affairs, they also relied on dedication and requisition to be supplied by locally influential people.
During the actual military affairs, they also relied on dedication and requisition to be supplied by locally influential people.

sen.j: 中世以後は一国平均役の一環として徴収される例が見られ、特に源平合戦においては平家・河内源氏双方が兵粮米の賦課を行っている。
sen.e: After the medieval period, hyoro was collected as part of Ikkoku heikinyaku (taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen [manor] and kokugaryo [provincial land] in a province), and especially during the Genpei War, both Heike; the Taira family and Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) imposed military provisions.

After the medieval period, hyoro was collected as part of Ikkoku heikinyaku (taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen [manor] and kokugaryo [provincial land] in a province), and especially during the Genpei War, both Heike; the Taira family and Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) imposed military provisions.

After the medieval period, hyoro was collected as part of Ikkoku heikinyaku (taxes and labor uniformly imposed on shoen [manor] and kokugaryo [provincial land] in a province), and especially during the Genpei War, both Heike; the Taira family and Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) imposed military provisions.

sen.j: だが、現地における兵粮米の賦課・徴発は兵士による濫妨を招く可能性があった。
sen.e: However, imposition and commandeering of military provisions in the field could cause solders' act of violence.
However, imposition and commandeering of military provisions in the field could cause solders' act of violence.
However, imposition and commandeering of military provisions in the field could cause solders' act of violence.

sen.j: 文治元年（1185年）に源頼朝が守護・地頭の設置求めて文治の勅許を受けると、同時に荘園・国衙領の田1段から兵粮米5升を徴収する権利を得た。
sen.e: In1185, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo asked the Imperial Court for permission to place Shugo and Jito (military governor and estate steward) and got the Bunji imperial sanction, and at the same time, he also gained a right to collect five sho (about 9 liter) of military provisions of rice from every one tan (an old unit showing the area of land of 300 tsubo; 991.7 square meters) of rice paddy of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).
sen.cmt: ・設置求めて→設置を求めて原文では「を」が抜けています。・設置を「朝廷に」求めたとみなし、訳出しました。
sen.e: In1185, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo asked the Imperial Court for permission to place Shugo and Jito (military governor and estate steward) and got the Bunji imperial sanction, and at the same time, he also gained a right to collect five sho (about 9 liter) of military provisions of rice from every one tan (an old unit showing the area of land of 300 tsubo; 991.7 square meters) of rice paddy of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).

In1185, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo asked the Imperial Court for permission to place Shugo and Jito (military governor and estate steward) and got the Bunji imperial sanction, and at the same time, he also gained a right to collect five sho (about 9 liter) of military provisions of rice from every one tan (an old unit showing the area of land of 300 tsubo; 991.7 square meters) of rice paddy of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).

sen.j: だが、国司・荘園領主達の反発が強く、翌年には撤回された。
sen.e: However, he faced strong opposition from Kokushi (provincial governor) and lords of the manor and this right was taken back in the following year.
However, he faced strong opposition from Kokushi (provincial governor) and lords of the manor and this right was taken back in the following year.
However, he faced strong opposition from Kokushi (provincial governor) and lords of the manor and this right was taken back in the following year.

tit.e: the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties - the Sengoku period (period of warring states)
the period of the Northern and Southern Courts - the Sengoku period (period of warring states)
tit.cmt: 中国ではなく、日本の南北朝時代なので次のように訂正しました。 Dynasties → Courts
tit.e: the period of the Northern and Southern Courts - the Sengoku period (period of warring states)

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)に入ると、北朝 (日本)（室町幕府）は 兵粮料所（半済令参照のこと）を、南朝 (日本)は朝用分を設定して兵糧確保にあたった。
sen.e: In Northern and Southern Dynasties (Japan), the Northern Court (Japan) (Muromachi bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]) placed Hyoro-ryosho (See Hanzeirei) and the Southern Court (Japan) inflicted choyobun (taxation), and in these ways they both secured army provisions.

In the period of Northern and Southern Courts, the Northern Court (Japan) (Muromachi bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]) placed Hyoro-ryosho (See Hanzeirei) and the Southern Court (Japan) inflicted choyobun (taxation), and in these ways they both secured army provisions.
sen.cmt: 上記と同様、Dynasties (Japan) → Courts に訂正しました。 「南北朝時代」の「時代」が抜けていたので、文頭のInの後にthe period of を加えました。
sen.e: In the period of Northern and Southern Courts, the Northern Court (Japan) (Muromachi bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]) placed Hyoro-ryosho (See Hanzeirei) and the Southern Court (Japan) inflicted choyobun (taxation), and in these ways they both secured army provisions.

sen.j: 室町幕府や守護大名の職制では、御蔵奉行が兵糧確保の任務にあたっていたが、 戦国時代 (日本)には、平時より蔵入地を設置して兵粮確保に力を注ぎ、戦時に際して小荷駄奉行とその下に小荷駄隊を設けるのが一般的となった。
sen.e: In the official organizations of Muromachi bakufu and shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords), Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) undertook to secure army provisions, but in the Sengoku period (Japan), it became common to place directly-controlled land and invested energy in securing army provisions in peacetime, and prepare konidabugyo (the commissioner of rear-echelon support troops) and, under that, konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies) in wartime.

In the official organizations of Muromachi bakufu and shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords), Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) undertook to secure army provisions, but in the Sengoku period (Japan), it became common to place directly-controlled land and invested energy in securing army provisions in peacetime, and prepare konidabugyo (the commissioner of rear-echelon support troops) and, under that, konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies) in wartime.

In the official organizations of Muromachi bakufu and shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords), Okura bugyo (the magistrate of storehouse) undertook to secure army provisions, but in the Sengoku period (Japan), it became common to place directly-controlled land and invested energy in securing army provisions in peacetime, and prepare konidabugyo (the commissioner of rear-echelon support troops) and, under that, konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies) in wartime.

sen.j: 豊臣政権によって兵農分離が進められると、武士が兵士としての役目を行うことが原則となるとともに兵糧携帯の義務が廃されて、代わりに兵糧の調達・運搬は農民ら領民の義務とされた。
sen.e: When the Toyotomi Administration forwarded heinobunri (a separation of the warrior class in this domain from the soil), samurai (warriors) did their job as solders in principle and their obligation to carry army provisions was abolished, and then, instead of that, it became people of the domain like peasants who undertook obligations to supply and transport army provisions.

When the Toyotomi Administration forwarded heinobunri (a separation of the warrior class in this domain from the soil), samurai (warriors) did their job as soldiers in principle and their obligation to carry army provisions was abolished, and then, instead of that, it became people of the domain like peasants who undertook obligations to supply and transport army provisions.
sen.cmt: スペルミス： solders → soldiers に訂正しました。
sen.e: When the Toyotomi Administration forwarded heinobunri (a separation of the warrior class in this domain from the soil), samurai (warriors) did their job as soldiers in principle and their obligation to carry army provisions was abolished, and then, instead of that, it became people of the domain like peasants who undertook obligations to supply and transport army provisions.

sen.j: また、大名は戦時に備えてあらかじめ米や塩・味噌などの調達・輸送計画を立案してこれに基づいた兵糧調達・購入が行われ、円滑な軍隊動員が行われるようになった。
sen.e: Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) also supplied and purchased army provisions as they preformed a project to supply and transport food such as rice, salt and miso, which helped their smooth military mobilization.

Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) also supplied and purchased army provisions as they preformed a project to supply and transport food such as rice, salt and miso, which helped their smooth military mobilization.

Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) also supplied and purchased army provisions as they preformed a project to supply and transport food such as rice, salt and miso, which helped their smooth military mobilization.

sen.j: これと同時に現地における兵糧調達は原則として禁止されて濫妨や刈田は軍律によって厳しく禁じられることになった。
sen.e: At the same time it was prohibited in principle to supply army provisions in the field and violence and karita (to reap rice) were strictly banned by the martial law.
At the same time it was prohibited in principle to supply army provisions in the field and violence and karita (to reap rice) were strictly banned by the martial law.
At the same time it was prohibited in principle to supply army provisions in the field and violence and karita (to reap rice) were strictly banned by the martial law.
